Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: My phone buzzed for the third time in five minutes. I glanced at the screen—Mom again, asking if I’d eaten lunch and reminding me to call her back. I knew she expected a quick reply, maybe even a short chat about my day. But right now, I was on a call with Mr. Jenkins, a customer who’d been with our company for years. He was furious, his voice sharp as he questioned every detail of the new offer I was supposed to sell. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “Don’t let them hang up angry. Handle every objection.” I tried to focus on Mr. Jenkins’ concerns, but my mind kept drifting to Mom’s messages, picturing her waiting anxiously for my response. My hands trembled as I juggled the headset and my phone, torn between the duty to reassure my parent and the pressure to keep my job. The weight of both expectations pressed down on me, and I felt myself caught in the middle, unable to give either side what they needed from me.
